text: Cawson. So good evening, school board members.  to all of our Albemarle County Schools community. On Monday, we made a public announcement on the topic I'm about to address. However, in consultation with Mr. Page and with Ms. Colson, I think it is a good idea to repeat it during this board meeting.  Our default plan for reopening Albemarle County Public Schools for the 2021-22 school year will be to provide five days per week of in-person instruction at our school buildings and sites. This is based on at least four developments. The continued success of our mitigation strategies and practices  Updated guidance from the Centers for Disease Control that schools can consider a reduction in physical distancing guidelines from six feet to three feet provided face masks continue to be required for all students and staff. The success of the Blue Ridge Health Department's program to fully vaccinate ACPS staff who have sought vaccination and that soon may include offering vaccines to students as young as 12 years old.  And the recent legislation signed by our governor, Governor Northam, that takes effect on July 1 and requires all school divisions in Virginia to provide students in all grade levels with five days a week in-person instruction each week. Families still would be able to opt for virtual instruction. I previously said that by May the 6th, I would present to the school board my recommendation for how our  schools should operate when the new school year begins. I am prepared to say now to our board that we have begun planning to offer in-person five day per week instruction to all students beginning on August 23rd. The purpose of our extra meeting on May 6th will now be to explain how we will accomplish offering five days per week in person.  On May 6, I will provide more details about these plans and encourage suggestions from the board members on how we can improve upon that plan. My recommendation will be that the school board approve our plans as the default unless, of course, circumstances materially change. On a second note, we also have begun planning to offer a fully virtual elementary, middle, and high school for those families who prefer that choice.  And finally, on a third note, I announced on Monday that our schools will remain in our current stage four for the remainder of the 2020-21 school year. There is a careful balance in place right now to ensure there is adequate staff to support in-person students. The same is true of our transportation network. We currently employ more than 560 different bus routes to bring students to and from school.  Disturbing this balance at this late date in the school year would detract from our ability to make our current Stage 4 plan work as designed. That doesn't mean that moving forward the needs of all of our students are not very much on my mind and on our mind. We understand many of our students have likely suffered learning losses and have missed their interactions with teachers and their classmates. It's why we are doing something this summer that is a rarity for any school division.  We're offering summer programming to all students whose families choose to participate. At all of our schools, well, provided through all of our schools and at various school sites, we will be providing both a morning session devoted to academic enrichment and an afternoon session in collaboration with community partners to promote student social and emotional health and physical fitness. I hope as many of our families as possible will join us with this summer  to enable their children to benefit from this new enrichment program and reconnect with their peers in a safe, healthy, and fulfilling environment. Of course, we will hear more about our recovery plans tonight during the work session. Ms. Colson, thank you very much for giving me the floor for a few minutes.

text: Good evening, my name is Jamie Gelner, Division Program Evaluator. In March, Dr. Acuff stated in her motion that ACPS provides additional funding for schools in the division based on the percent of low-income students enrolled at each school, that is students who are eligible for free and reduced lunch.  This differentiated funding introduced approximately 20 years ago is used to provide additional staffing resources to improve educational achievement. She specifically asked if the differentiated funding is the best tool to address these gaps and if an income-only based model is the metric to use. Dr. Acuff's request is primarily research-based and questions if the strategy we're using is the most appropriate.  Because of the nature of this evaluation question, we are proposing the following guiding questions for this evaluation. What are the best strategies to equitably fund schools to close achievement gaps according to current research? What funding strategies have actually been most impactful in closing achievement gaps in Virginia? How does ACPS allocate funding to all schools? How is the additional staffing used?  What impacts on student achievement are we able to identify as a result of this funding strategy? And what other funding models may ACPS consider? Attached to the board's item tonight, there was some preliminary research from EAB around differentiated funding models for equity. ACPS uses one model of differentiated funding, but there are, in fact, many ways that divisions differentiate funding.  The evaluation will provide mainly a research brief that outlines options for other differentiated funding models and explains the process by which ACPS differentiates funding for schools. We would also answer if ACPS funding strategies are best practice strategies and find out what other Virginia divisions are doing to close gaps. text: Thank you, Ms. Collins. I'm Jennifer Sublett, Director of the Professional Learning Department. Our purpose tonight is to frame how we plan to address learning recovery as a school system and community of learners in the months and years ahead.
speaker: jennifersuble

text: Tonight, we will share the guiding principles and desired outcomes developed by our project team.
speaker: jennifersuble

text: In an effort to give concrete examples of how these principles will be actualized, we will dig into two key strategies that will help us achieve our desired outcomes. We will also look at how our model for summer programming will serve as a foundation for learning recovery and is aligned to our guiding principles. There are a lot of elements to this project, and we will try to be both clear and comprehensive in our overview tonight.  Our goal is to get feedback from the board on the vision our team is building for learning recovery and these first strategies that we have identified. We first framed our approach to learning recovery this spring during the superintendent's budget request. As we explained then, we have been focused on attending to urgent needs of our students and teachers brought about by the pandemic and the transition to virtual and then hybrid instruction. As we move forward into the summer and next year, we're transitioning into a period of recovery  This is an opportunity to focus our efforts on strategies and best practices that we know have high levels of impact for all students. This is also an opportunity for us to learn from the experience of the past year and focus our efforts on what we have learned is most essential for students. While this year has been challenging to say the least, there is opportunity in the powerful positive power of disruption that will support transformation and rebuilding.  I would like to begin by providing an overview of how our project team has created a framework to organize our work in order to plan coordinated efforts across departments to support students. Given the iterative process of planning, implementing, and evaluating that will be needed during this period of recovery, our team first co-constructed guiding principles that will shape our decision-making and setting the priorities. As you can see in these principles, there is a direct alignment  to our school system's vision and mission, as well as our equity mission. We've provided a link to our full guiding principles document in the notes of this presentation for more information and detail. From these principles, we set about determining our long-term outcomes. Beyond the goal of making sure that student academic achievement levels return to or exceed pre-pandemic levels,  Our outcomes will also address the social, emotional, and wellness needs brought about by the conditions of the past year. I would like to point out that we are keenly aware that the learning environment of the school year has impacted not just our students, but also our teachers, families, and community at large. We want to partner with all stakeholders and seek to ensure that our efforts provide benefits across these groups.  Finally, I want to share a link to the initial logic model the team has drafted to identify key strategies to meet our outcomes. We see this document as a working document that will evolve and grow as we reflect on our progress towards our outcomes. Again, this is an incredibly complex project. We invite you to take time to review our current logic model, which we've linked here. So we see our work as a series of multiple plan-do-study-act cycles.  This will allow us to respond to current needs with thoughtful strategies that are then monitored and evaluated for their impact. What you see here is a schema for our first PDSA cycle around planning for summer program support, which we will spotlight later on in this presentation. So in summary, we're being careful to make sure that our approach to learning recovery takes into account the whole student. Again, this is not a new focus for our division.  and it highlights the point that recovery is about focusing on high-impact strategies that align to our educational philosophy and core values as a school system. We'll begin tonight's deeper dive into our approach to learning recovery with a focus on academic achievement. As we do that, we think it is important to reframe our efforts from a focus on learning loss to a focus on learning opportunities. This work is a chance to reignite our commitment to consistent application  of high-impact strategies and to do so with fidelity. Tonight, we will look at student self-efficacy and how student goal-setting and self-reflection are critical components of building self-efficacy. Student self-efficacy is a perfect example of a critical component of student success. Research shows a relationship between high levels of efficacy and student achievement. Furthermore, student self-efficacy is interdependent with student social-emotional learning.  and aligns to our division's commitment to culturally responsive teaching and its focus on creating active, independent learners through the formation of learning partnerships. As Aretha Hammond notes, the ultimate goal is to help students take over the reins of their learning. If they are to become independent, we have to provide them with the tools. So to understand how to provide students those tools for success and independence, we have to first unpack self-advocacy.  In his visible learning work, John Hattie refers to student self-efficacy as a student's perception of their capacity for success and ranks it as one of the top high-yield strategies in education. In short, high self-efficacy is the confidence or strength of belief that one can learn and experience success in learning. Low self-efficacy is a lack of that confidence. This is important because students tend to avoid tasks that they think exceed their ability and seek tasks at which they think they can succeed.  Therefore, self-efficacy judgments affect which activities students choose or avoid, how much effort they put into learning tasks, and how much resilience they have, and how long they'll persist with a task. We've linked a short video clip of Hattie on this topic in the presentation notes, in case you want to dive even further. The importance of student self-efficacy is clear, and its potential impact on student achievement is great. However, our task is to identify concrete strategies that we can implement  which are shown to increase self-efficacy. It is not enough for us to merely hope students gain more confidence in their potential. We must purposefully create the learning conditions and experiences that do that. This graphic outlines a framework for integrating a system of strategies that provide those conditions for every student. By focusing on students setting goals that are created with their teacher and personalized to their learning needs, we help them become an active partner in their learning. Furthermore,  by setting up systems for them to self-assess their progress and share that reflection in their own learning conference, they take ownership of their learning. I would like to point out that these are reflective processes based on the critical relationship between students and teachers, and students, teachers, and families. As such, they are manageable in terms of implementation, but deeply meaningful in their impact. Having looked at a high-yield strategy for academic achievement,  We will now turn to social-emotional learning needs and their relationship to student success in school and beyond. Again, we see this as an opportunity to re-engage with a focus area that has been a priority for us and to do so with the goal of improving our support of students. The Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning, or CASEL, is the preeminent resource for research on supporting SEL development.  CASEL defines social-emotional learning as the process through which all young people and adults acquire and apply the knowledge, skills, and attitudes that allow them to develop healthy identities, manage emotions, and achieve personal and collective goals, feel and show empathy for others, establish and maintain supportive relationships, and make responsible and caring decisions. As we review this definition, you can see the link to academic learning and to the strategies to support student self-efficacy described earlier.

So we're excited to now turn to provide an overview of our model for summer programming with students. We really do see this as the launch of our learning recovery work. As such, our goal is that our model for programming aligns to the principles of our learning recovery model. So again, we're committed to a focus on equity, the whole child,  personalized learning and relationships. With careful consideration of the types of learning and social activities that students have missed most and the toll that virtual and hybrid instruction has taken on our families and community, we've expanded and enhanced our summer program for students. One of the most exciting aspects of this expansion is partnering with community organizations and businesses to make high quality programming available to our elementary and middle school students.  and to support our families with a full day, full week program for our students. Knowing that many students missed out on the interactions of in-person summer activities in 2020, and that in-person time with peers was limited this school year, we prioritize making a full week of programming available for all elementary and middle school students. We will run this programming for the entire month of July and invite those students who have significant academic intervention needs to attend for all four weeks. At the high school level,  Our goal is to help students who have fallen behind in course credits. We know that the virtual environment has been a challenge for some, and so we're moving to an in-person credit recovery approach. High school students will get personalized support with their teachers. To help us in our planning for an expanded summer program, we surveyed families to gauge interest in participating in morning and afternoon programs. This was not a registration or formal commitment, but it did help us to plan strategically. We see high levels of interest in participating this summer.  And when asked about priorities, we see that our families share interest in supporting academic and SEL opportunities. It is interesting when we asked them that they could select other, I went back and asked Chris Gilman, what did they, I don't have any data on what the other was, because they all said all of the above. So anyone who said other was, they then wrote in all of the above. Beyond academics, families were able to weigh in on types of activities that they thought students would most enjoy the summer. Again, you can see the variety of topics, but also the inclusion of time with peers.  Here's a framework of what a student's schedule will look like. In the morning, ACPS staff will work with students on focused academic instruction and engaging problem-based learning that is creative and collaborative. In the afternoon, students have the option to remain at school and participate in engaging summer camp-like activities. To build out the afternoon programming, we completed a request for proposals through the procurement process. Because of the regulations of the RFP process, at this time we cannot share which organizations will be providing programming, but we will do so as soon as that process is complete.  However, we are so pleased with the response we got to our RFP from businesses and organizations within our community. We really value their willingness to partner with us. We'd like to dig into what we mean by focusing on problem-based learning with our students. This summer, we are excited that funding is allowing us to fully implement a nationally recognized program called Camp Invention. Working with the National Association of Inventors, Camp Invention is a hands-on STEM-based PBL program that supports students in critical and creative thinking.  Each student receives a comprehensive kit with all the materials they need to build not only a finished product, but also to build conceptual understandings and creative thinking skills. Teachers are able to use the program as a springboard for creating connections with traditional academic subjects, such as science, math, and literature.
